Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Ecological and Neuroanatomical Correlates of Mating System Variation in the Taiwan Field Vole

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecological variation, both between and within species, has been demonstrated to cause variation in mating systems. In mammals, social pair bonding and biparental care of offspring, both key components of a monogamous mating system, seem to be controlled by two neuropeptides –oxytocin and vasopressin– acting in the reward and reinforcement regions of the brain. I proposed an integrative model which posits ecological variation causes variation in mating system strategies through natural selection, which acts upon the genes encoding neuropeptide receptors in the brain. To this end, I studied the impact of ecological variation on the mating system and neuroanatomy of the Taiwan field vole (Microtus kikuchii). While the genetic components underlying mating system behavior were beyond the scope of this research, my work is novel in that I studied the ecological and neuroanatomical correlates of mating system variation in naturally occurring populations of the same species. I also sought to determine oxytocin and vasopressin receptor distributions in the Taiwan vole brain, which have never been quantified in this species. Live trapping was conducted in meadow and forest sites from April to August in 2009 and 2010. Vole brains were then collected and treated with oxytocin or vasopressin receptor autoradiography to determine receptor binding densities in crucial reward regions of the brain.

This species expresses high levels of vasopressin receptor binding in the reward and reinforcement regions of the brain, consistent with other monogamous voles, mice and primates. Taiwan voles also express high levels of oxytocin receptors in the prefrontal cortex and insular cortex, both reward and reinforcement regions of the brain, but express low oxytocin receptor binding in the nucleus accumbens. Oxytocin receptor binding in the nucleus accumbens plays an important role in both parents providing parental care to their offspring and is considered critical for pair-bond formation in female rodents. Thus, low oxytocin receptor binding in the nucleus accumbens suggests Taiwan voles display less biparental care, oxytocin binding in the nucleus accumbens is not sufficient in determining pair-bond formation or their mating system is controlled, in part, by alternative mechanisms.

This research developed and utilized an integrative model that allows us to better understand how ecology and neurobiology affects social behavior. It marks a rare attempt to quantify receptor expression in natural populations using a new model organism. By quantifying oxytocin and vasopressin receptor distributions in a novel species, I have furthered our understanding on the relationships between ecology, neuroanatomical substrates and social behavior. This study can also help determine if differences in neuropeptide receptor binding are linked to differences in social behavior. By mapping the receptor binding levels in the Taiwan vole, I have provided a basis of comparison for future research on this species.


Last Modified: 09/07/2012
Modified by: Amanda R Chappell
